√âvaluation publi√©e le 2 juillet 2017
–ò–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä–µ—Å–Ω–∞—è –∏–≥—Ä—É—à–∫–∞,—Å—Ç–∏–ª–∏—Å—Ç–∏–∫–∞ –∫–ª–∞—Å—Å–Ω–∞—è,—É—á–∏—Ç—ã–≤–∞—è —Å–∫–∏–¥–∫—É –≤ 75%,—Ç–∞–∫ –≤–æ–æ–±—â–µ —Å—É–ø–µ—Ä. –¢–æ–ª—å–∫–æ –≤–æ—Ç –∏–≥—Ä–∞—Ç—å –≤ –Ω–µ–µ –Ω–µ –≤–æ–∑–º–æ–∂–Ω–æ - –≤ –ª—é–±–æ–π –º–æ–º–µ–Ω—Ç –º–æ–∂–Ω–æ –ø—Ä–æ–≤–∞–ª–∏—Ç—å—Å—è —Å–∫–≤–æ–∑—å —Ç–µ–∫—Å—Ç—É—Ä—ã. –ü–æ 10 —Ä–∞–∑ —É—Ä–æ–≤–µ–Ω—å –ø—Ä–∏—Ö–æ–¥–∏—Ç—Å—è –ø—Ä–æ—Ö–æ–¥–∏—Ç—å, –Ω–æ –≤–æ–∑–≤—Ä–∞—Ç –¥–µ–ª–∞—Ç—å –Ω–µ –±—É–¥—É,–ø–æ–¥–æ–∂–¥—É –ø–∞—Ç—á–µ–π.
 
Rust
0
Personne n'a trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Recommand√©
3.2 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 2 mai 2019
In short: This is a novel gravity-driven platform-puzzler with smart level design, which rewards formulating plans and thinking ahead. The soothing atmosphere and great interface make it highly enjoyable to play. The pricing more than adequately reflects the total playtime of 3-4 hours.

In long: Your task is to navigate the floating structures of each of the 30 levels in first-person perspective until you reach the door at the end. Walking across curved ramps seamlessly changes gravity. At first the main mechanics are just these ramps and dropping off ledges. Later on knobs to rotate some structures, switches that toggle between light and dark platforms and portals are introduced. These very simple elements are assembled beautifully into complex challenges.
Despite its name I actually didn't find gameplay to be all too disorienting. At any point you can enter view mode, which puts you into third person and allows you to freely rotate the camera. It didn't feel all that useful until I realized you can zoom out with mouse wheel, which gives you pretty much a perfect view of the whole level. You can use this mode to plan your actions, which is an increasingly important aspect as the levels get harder. Since you can and often have to walk off edges, you can totally screw yourself by falling onto a platform from which you cannot escape. This is thankfully mitigated by a brilliant feature allowing you to manually checkpoint whenever you want. When used smartly (i.e. only when you know you're on the right track) you never have to restart a level. Still, this is not a game for mindless trial and error. It pays to pause, really think about a level, calmy formulate a plan and to mentally map out the effects of the various switches in case you need them later on.
With respects to the difficulty the game is not overly hard. The first 10 levels are pretty straight-forward before it admittedly starts getting a bit mind-bendy. While levels might look daunting (the store page screenshots seem to be the most confusing and crowded angles - these levels look simpler in-game), usually the solutions follow a linear path. Complexity does increase, but there are never more than 1 or 2 sensible next steps to actually advance, so I never felt overwhelmed. The hardest steps to figure out are the times when you have to drop down, since there is no obvious indication when to use this mechanic. But once I got used to the "language" of the game, it felt like everything had a fairly logical flow. The first 15 levels took me about 50min. I don't know why, but level 23 gave me considerable difficulty and took me 25min to beat. Everything else was much easier, with later levels ranging from 5-12min. Beating the game on my first play-through took me a little over 3 hours. With just 30 levels the game does feel a bit short, but all the levels are well designed and none felt like filler. I could see myself maybe going back to this game after a few years.

In terms of presentation I would put the game above average. The artsy minimalist low-fi graphics certainly aren't for everyone but after playing for a little while I grew quite fond of them. They're clean and functional. I think it would have been very easy to make this look much worse with texures. There is a nice low-key ambient music through-out. I normally don't like background music in puzzle games, but here it turned out to be really pleasant. The sound effects are decent as well. It all contributes to a very calming, zen-like atmosphere.

On the technical side I was very impressed by the game's low hardware demands. Even though it's a 3D game it runs perfectly on my integrated Intel HD 4000 graphics chip, even with antialiasing. The menu options are truly exemplary: Separate volume sliders with a master slider on top, various graphical options including FOV, mouse sensitivity slider, customizable keyboard controls - I love everything about this! The game starts in full-screen but windowed mode is available. The window is resized by dragging on the edges and the size is remembered across sessions. Well done!

In conclusion I had a lot of fun with this non-conventional puzzle game. The interface and menus are a delight. The levels themselves are interesting and challenging, complex but never overwhelming. I enjoyed mapping out my routes in third person camera mode and then executing them in first person. I'm pretty sure that I never actually deviated from intended solutions, but making precarious drops and touching buttons around corners gave a nice tingly feeling of maybe breaking the rules of the game. The atmosphere is nicely calming. 30 levels of unique content for a playtime of a little over 3 hours is a bit short, but perfectly adequate for the asking price (especially on sale). I can definitely recommend this game for fans of puzzles, rational planning and spatial thinking.
 
Gatebase
0

√âvaluation publi√©e le 11 octobre 2018

Ugly-Toe
0
3 personnes ont trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
1 personne a trouv√© cette √©valuation amusante
0
Recommand√©
10.4 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 15 janvier 2017
Disoriented is a simplistic first person view puzzle game, set within a three dimensional abstract bent-space labyrinth environment. The aim of each level is to find the way out. Visually it resembles Antichamber and thematically the upcoming [2017] Manifold Garden, which presumably are the strongest marketing catches Disoriented has on STEAM.

The gameplay to myself feels lacking further challenge or purpose, despite the puzzles growing gradually more tricky and the aim of each stage being clear. Perhaps it is the case of murky "zen" factor. The difficulty curve starts low, therefore if you find the early maps too easy, skip it to the second page. The developer is enganged in the project and responsive, therefore additional contents may eventually be expected.

All in all, if you are keen on puzzlegames and seek something to stretch up your mind, Disoriented may as well be the choice, especially if you are particularly into the first person view style. The score is 6/10 wHATs grade. Recommendable to fanboys of the minimalist design. The price of four Euro is approachable. Nonetheless, if you expect Disoriented to bestow you with a second Antichamber experience, let go of it.

I would also like to point out first person view puzzle games have already been discovered, even the ones featuring bizarre physics.
 
76561198292631324
0
13 personnes ont trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
3 personnes ont trouv√© cette √©valuation amusante
0
Recommand√©
6.7 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 30 septembre 2017
‚ñà‚ñÄ‚ñà‚ñë ‚ñà‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñà‚ñë ‚ñà‚ñÄ‚ñÄ‚ñë ‚ñÑ‚ñÄ‚ñÄ‚ñÑ‚ñë ‚ñÑ‚ñÄ‚ñÄ‚ñÄ‚ñÑ‚ñë ‚ñà‚ñÄ‚ñÑ‚ñÄ‚ñà‚ñë ‚ñà‚ñÄ‚ñÄ
‚ñà‚ñÄ‚ñà‚ñë ‚ñà‚ñë‚ñà‚ñë‚ñà‚ñë ‚ñà‚ñÄ‚ñë‚ñë ‚ñÄ‚ñÑ‚ñÑ‚ñÑ‚ñë ‚ñà‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñà‚ñë ‚ñà‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñà‚ñë ‚ñà‚ñÄ‚ñë

√âvaluation publi√©e le 23 mai 2023
A minimalist game with very maze-like puzzles. It's okay. I suppose it was worth the 99 cents I paid for it.

The only problem I have with it is that the only way to tell what switches do is by activating them, meaning you have to rely on memory (or brute force). The same goes for where the button platforms appear.
 
nickwhitestreak

√âvaluation publi√©e le 14 d√©cembre 2022
Is not a puzzle if your objetive is undone what the dev made, there is 3 actions you can do in this game: Move, (kinda) run, and use checkpoints. I bought this thinking it would be like Antichamber (a game millions times better), but is just a boring "get from point A to B" and i wasted 3 hours of my life in this.

An advice for the dev: Next time try to play puzzle games like the beforementioned ntichamber, Portal, Half Life, and others before making your own game.

A simple premise yet grows complex over time, levels are engaging and well paced. The seems to be a bug in the last level where block rotation is not reverted after falling to death, making it easier than intended. Otherwise a good game.
 
UserNameReducted
0
Personne n'a trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Recommand√©
0.2 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 8 mai 2022
Especially considering the price point, this is a fantastic little puzzle game. It reminds me a lot of another newer title called, Frame of Mind. They share some DNA.

One could arguably say both of them are more artistic experiences than games. However, where they diverge is FoM is a free title that was a student project. Where as this is much more firmly in the game category (though both of them do for sure qualify as games by any measure). This game doesn't really explain itself to you, but it also doesn't really need to. If you just start playing you'll figure it out pretty quickly.

Once you understand how it works, it becomes an exercise in demonstrating logic in conjunction with spatial awareness. If you lack spatial awareness, then I suppose this game will present a challenge will boarder on frustrating. If you have it, or if you are ok with that, then this game is for you. If you need to understand what you are doing and why, then you should probably move along, this one is not for you.

But as for myself, this is great.
 
Nicodemous52
434 produits enregistr√©s
0
Personne n'a trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Recommand√©
5.1 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 8 mai 2022
It's the 'Dark Souls' of "non-euclid" first person gravitational mazes.
The puzzles, the gimmick of which is mastering the navigation in X Y Z planes and using levers and switches to create new paths, are really good and so is the presentation, where you can certainly feel the touch of Antichamber, with the flowing river and occasional wind bell ambient noises scattered around the sparsely painted area,
but it's very monotonous and occasionally frustrating with the puzzles, as the game doesn't handhold you through certain essential things, like jumping off a ledge (the trick is to never land on a platform without its own U / J-shaped ledge that you can use to 'go back')

I think in this absolute vacuum of the gameplay "roller coaster" design (where developers switch the pace of the action from slow to fast to break the monotony), changing visuals or engaging plot, bundled with some quirky dialogues, achievements are the only thing that can motivate the player to solve all of the puzzles, but when you beat that last of its 30 levels - you'll feel like a million bucks.
 
matrixdll
2,402 produits enregistr√©s

√âvaluation publi√©e le 22 aout 2021
I have vertigo... Much like Parallax and Manifold Garden, this is a game I will never finish. I like the concept of the game. I even like the first twelve 11 puzzles that I have now played twice... but I also have vertigo and just can't go past level 12. The game just makes me ill. And that's not something a game should do. If you don't have a problem with heights and falling and like puzzles I recoomend this game, as well as the other two mentioned above. If you do have a problem with heights... maybe give this one a pass.

Alexsandro de Souza
0
Personne n'a trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Recommand√©
4.5 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 4 juillet 2021
3D-Puzzle with a switching perspective etc. I enjoyed the first 15-20 level but than it turned out to be trickier.
A little reminder: If you quit the game, it wont safe your times for each stages.
I want to quote JimDeadlock:
"This is a 3D puzzle game in a similar style to games like The Bridge, Evo Explores and Monument Valley but there are two major differences:

There are no optical illusions - no bridges appear over gaps when obscured, there's no mind-bending twisting of perspective or anything like that, it's all logical and mechanical.

It's a first-person perspective. This makes a big difference in the way you play the levels because you can't get an overall view of the whole puzzle. It's like the difference between solving a maze from above or from within it."

recommend it!
 
JS
888 produits enregistr√©s
0
Personne n'a trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Recommand√©
4.1 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 21 mars 2021
Fun puzzle game, enjoyed my time with it. Not the hardest one in the world, but there were a couple stumpers that required coming back to. It's about 4 hours worth of play on my end. I wasn't speeding through it, and I wasn't following a walkthrough at all. Like I said, I had to come back to at least one of them, but it's the "disorientation" that forms the fundamental weirdness of trying to solve these puzzles.

The more apt you are to thinking in those terms, the faster you'll naturally be able to puzzle through the game; otoh, if that kind of thing makes you sick or your head hurt, then I would advise you to avoid this game.

If you like puzzle games and find the price of this one to be reasonable for ~3-6 hrs of entertainment, I'd say go for it.
 
Rick St. Riot

Personne n'a trouv√© cette √©valuation utile

Recommand√©
2.6 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 14 f√©vrier 2021
So overall I liked this game. It's a good little puzzle game. BUT I didn't enjoy the feeling of falling into the abyss. Also had issues with saves. Basically nothing seems to save once you close the game so if you want the achievements, do it all in one go. And it is BLINDINGLY white. I turned down the brightness on my monitor significantly and it was still too much.
 
curbsy
0
Personne n'a trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Recommand√©
1.0 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 16 janvier 2021
An interesting idea, however it lacks in actually good puzzle mechanics. One is a light switch where you just have to memorize different paths more than actually thinking about where they could help you, one just rotates a part of the map (which is in no way highlighted while it's NOT moving). Both are even the same color so you sometimes don't even know which one is which if you're far away.

This resulted in me not thinking beforehand but just running with it. Most of the time I only had one path to follow and somehow it ended up being the correct one. Some rooms I didn't even understand but got through them on the first try.

More of a memory game than a puzzle game for sure.

TL;DR cool for a new experience, not recommended as a puzzle game. For this money, I liked the new idea.
 
Panossa

Tem a dificuldade espacial que n√£o √© t√£o comum em jogos de puzzles, o que √© um ponto positivo, nos faz exercitar algo diferente de outros puzzles. As vezes acaba se resolvendo na sorte, o que n√£o √© t√£o gratificante quanto por racioc√≠nio e m√©rito pr√≥prio. Um ponto negativo √© n√£o ter op√ß√£o de "voltar no tempo" ao cair, vc pode salvar sempre q quiser e o jogo salva automaticamente algumas coisas (como as po√ßas que tem de ativar), mas seria muito mellhor poder voltar no tempo ao cair e focar mais nos puzzles, do que cair e ter de voltar pro local ou ficar salvando a todo momento.

Pretty meh. It's not a bad game, it's not buggy or looks bad, but there are better games to fill your time. 4 hours was enough to 100% the game without looking anything up, so if you want a relatively short experience then go for it. It is also a bit nauseating, so if you get sick playing first-person games, you'll probably feel a little queasy.

√âvaluation publi√©e le 27 juillet 2020
Neat little puzzle game. In puzzle games, I usually try to find the solution by thinking of the steps backwards, and this game gave me a challenge because it can be tough to get a sense of where you are. It really is "disorienting" in a good way! It uses the first person perspective well and also takes good advantage of 3d space.

0
Personne n'a trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Recommand√©
0.3 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 28 juin 2020
A nice simplistic short game. Game has 30 levels. Shamefully doesn't take the concept of disorientation very far. While playing it I was comparing it in my own head to "Monument valley". I would have benefited from levels with wierd geometry and world portals you can find in source engine.

Anyway, fun if you like a bit of simple puzzling in 3d space. I got it on the steam sale for 0,47 euro's. Which is my opinion is "cheap" but I would probably not play more then 1 euro for it.
 
Enes
744 produits enregistr√©s
0
Personne n'a trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
1 personne a trouv√© cette √©valuation amusante
0
Non recommand√©
0.3 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 5 f√©vrier 2020
Concept is great. Price is great. I appreciate the minimalistic art style. But I only made it 20 minutes and I'm extremely nauseous now. I feel like I've just had a really, really bad VR experience. Problem is it takes a long time to get over the motion sickness feeling. I couldn't tell what was worse, the free falling when you fell off the walkways or the curved ramps.

Great that you're given the camera system to be able to zoom out and rotate around to help with figuring out your path but you absolutely need a character of some kind to show your current location when you're in the camera mode. Currently you have no idea where you're standing, there's no representation of your character while in this view mode. I think it wasn't put in as it would have taken away from the minimalistic look of the game but even something very faint, doesn't even have to be a person, just some sort of shadow or something to let you know where you were standing would have helped.

...Been well over an hour now after having stopped playing and still have this motion sickness. Terrible.

Check out Manifold Garden instead. Costs a bit more but that one is a masterpiece.
 
Y4F9

Personne n'a trouv√© cette √©valuation utile

At first I got worried that it won't deliver, because there was no USE button in the settings, and you can only do so much with changing world-rotation. Fortunately, you could use stuff around you with LMB and the game was great. We lived happily ever after, though every day I wished that disappearing platforms would leave some sort of a trace when off. The end <3

√âvaluation publi√©e le 31 d√©cembre 2019
I don't understand why, but the developer seems to have abandoned the game, and removed controller support. While I love the game, do be warned that the only controller supported is the Steam controller (because of the ability to map buttons to keyboard keys and mouse movement).

It really is a shame the game's development is over, because this is a great game if you like first-person puzzle games. It is a bit short, but some of the levels are crazy hard.

8/10, buy it on sale when you can

Handsomeless King
273 produits enregistr√©s
0
Personne n'a trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Recommand√©
2.8 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 2 juillet 2019
I really like the minimalist graphics, the ease of motion and camera control, and the challenging play. However, I did get stuck after 12 levels, and wanted to have a friend catch up to me to discuss. We share a computer but have our own logins and Steam accounts, but this game has only one saved state, and my friend only saw my progress and could not start the game anew. Most games here on Steam do honor the user directories, so this is an oversight from the publisher. I had to dig into my Windows directory to manually delete my save files. Otherwise, the game is well-made.
 
kdeflane

√âvaluation publi√©e le 20 mai 2019
if you're drawn to this by your love of antichamber be wary. It stands alone as a fun minimalist escherian puzzler but steam recommends it in "may also like" for antichamber and you should know the similarities end at the aesthetic and it being a puzzle game.

It's fun to figure it out, it has the one core mechanic and 2 ways to manipulate the environment across 30 discrete puzzles.

Good puzzle, but one blemish, player can fall off beams anywhere, would it not better if player only fell off it if there were another beam underneath to land on? If there are multiple beams then I see no issue that puzzle element is still intact but game would not needlessly aggrevating.

That is aggrevation for sure but otherwise the puzzle is solid, had it featuring some primitive scoring then it would make it a game; otherwise a nice diversion not much more.

A superb game! Absolutely loved it!

In the beginning few levels it felt a little confusing. After that I was able to plan out where I want to go for most parts of the level.

All the levels are beautifully designed. I needed to refer to some guides in the first 15 levels (not much, probably 2-3 ocassions). After that I was able to complete the full thing without any further help.

303 produits enregistr√©s

Personne n'a trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Recommand√©
3.2 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 4 janvier 2019
This is a very interesting and relaxing puzzle game. It really bends your brain to try and see the pathways from every angle all at once. It helps to have the ability to step back and see the whole puzzle to plan out the route to the end, even though it took a second or two to figure out the controls for it.

All in all, this is a great little puzzle game that helps to improve spatial thinking while having a calming atmosphere to boot.

Oof... Disoriented. They weren't kidding.

I've never gotten motion sickness from a video game before; 10 minutes into this and I was starting to taste vomit.

Still a fun game, though. Just a warning.
 
verybigcat
238 produits enregistr√©s
0
Personne n'a trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
1 personne a trouv√© cette √©valuation amusante
0
Non recommand√©
1.0 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 3 octobre 2018
Disoriented is one of these games that I really WANT to be good. Clever Idea, well crafted mechanics, great art style.
But in the end I rage quitted the game for the 3rd time now (this time at level 13 of 30).

The problem lies in information visualization. The game won't show you the effects of pressing a button until you press it. E.g. when you press the light switch (see trailer) you don't know where new bridges might appear and you have to remember the bridges that disappeared yourself. Does not seem like that big of a problem - until you combine it with the changing gravity.

The game game is already hard weird to navigate. So the lack of information leaves you with running around the level remembering it by heart OR brute force your way via trial-and-error.

With a little more information (like the rotatable level parts beeing blue and the "light switch bridges" showing their outlines in gray even when they are inactive), I would have enjoyed the whole game a lot. But sadly I as it is I have to give up on this game again with a headache.
 
Jinx Pliskin
0
Personne n'a trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Recommand√©
9.6 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 14 aout 2018
Visual-spatial acuity is not one of my strengths so I was not sure if this game would be something I enjoy, but I really love it. Sure it probably takes me longer to solve a level than most people but hey I'm just getting more bang for my buck that way, right? I would love to see a version of this game with some beautiful graphics, I think that would be amazing, however I also appreciate the simplicity of the style here, especially at this moment when my gaming computer is in the shop again and I am struggling to find games that play on my lowest-end back up laptop. Which this one does perfectly :) I want a sequel!

√âvaluation publi√©e le 28 juin 2018
un juego neto de resoluci√≥n de puzzles, lo m√°s similar a transformar un cubo rubik en un juego.

contenedor de un desarrollo que inicia ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• una especie de tutorial incorporado en los niveles y finaliza cremando un par de neuronas.

controles que se sienten dociles y sin ningun tipo de glitchs o bugs. logros que se dan por si solos al ir progresando de nivel a nivel.

poseedor de una estatica minimalista y musica que pareciera ayudar a la resolucion de los puzzles.

quizas contiene un potencial para ser 'speedrun' pero solo es una cuestion de memorizar los puzzles.

vas a necesitar memoria y alguna vez; bastante 'ayuda'.

0.5 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 23 juin 2018
Refreshingly novel concept for a puzzle game. Simple enough gameplay that it can be casually approached without explanation.

Took me around 30 minutes to reach level 12 where I first got stuck. So I expect the total playtime will come in around 2-3 hours, reasonable considering the cost. (I'll try to remember to update the review when I get that far).

‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•:
* The alternate zoom out camera is a bit arkward to control
* Minor graphical artifacts (dark pixels that flicker for a second or two), some of these seem to appear at the seams between blocks, the cause of other less frequent artiefacts is unclear.

√âvaluation publi√©e le 16 avril 2018
A 3d puzzle where you can standing sideways, upside down relative to when the level started. Trying to figure where you are and how to get to where you want to be. At 99 cents you can't go wrong. Only problem I've had is several head slapping "DOH"!! moments when I realise I've been looking through the solution and not seeing it.

√âvaluation publi√©e le 10 avril 2018
A journey of a thousand miles starts with one.... wait a minute...I have already taken that step...lets try this step... That did not work either. Great now I have lost my steps... So if I take this step here...

Basically how this minimalistic puzzle game works. Really gets you to think out the box. Messes with your spacial orientation though. But all in all a really good puzzle game.

Sometimes a bit frustrating (aren't all puzzles), but most of the time relaxing and more importantly, rewarding. The puzzles are for the most part pretty good and challenging enough not to feel boring. I played a few levels every now and then to relax. It took me a few hours in total to finish the game, which I think is the perfect length for a game like this.

Personne n'a trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Recommand√©
10.3 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 12 novembre 2017
Excellent game! If you like geometric/topological puzzles, you should not miss this one. Aritiscally the graphics and music create a world of their own producing what I would describe as an atmospheric feeling. The levels progress in difficulty level, which reduces the learning curve and improve gameplay overall. There is also no needless background story, you are free to bring your own thoughts, feelings, theories or whatever and make the playing experience something more personal.
 
Rex Kramer

Personne n'a trouv√© cette √©valuation utile

Recommand√©
6.0 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 10 aout 2017
A refreshing puzzle game that gets progressively harder with each level. The mechanics are easy to understand, with only a few twists and turns - thankfully... Treat it with a casual mindset and the game will become easy. Overthinking leads to restarts. Really, there is only one way through each level and once you get the hang of it, you'll find it is perfectly laid out in front of you.
 
Sychon
0
Personne n'a trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Recommand√©
7.4 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 17 juillet 2017
1. Disoriented will kind of confuse and annoy you from time to time but it provides just enough hot puzzle solving action to be really worth playing if you are a fan of the genre.

2. You will get 660 achievements just for running the game. Thanks, game! I guess this annoys some people though.

3. It is apparently some sort of law that all first person puzzle games be compared to Portal. This is not as good as Portal but I feel saying that is equally as unimportant and meaningless as saying an album of music isn't as good as Pet Sounds.

4. A closer comparison might be Antichamber but this is way less stupid than that game. The rules don't change on you all the time.

5. I got nervous during the first dozen or so levels that this was going to wind up being some sort of walking sim w/ puzzle elements rather than a puzzle game. It's got that beatless synth music that just builds up slowly to nothing and the first few levels are trivial to beat on the first try. Thankfully, those are mostly just a tutorial.

6. It seems likely that the levels in this were designed in the order you play them. The level designs seem to get better as the game goes on. At some point, they released six new levels to add to the original game and those are astronomically better than the levels before it.

7. The name of the game is Disoriented, I get it but I feel like the devs should have done more to let you know where you are and what's going on. The gravity flipping mechanic this is build on is great but every level is solid plain white and gray and it's really hard to tell one section of the level from another. Every switch in the game is blue and there are frequently three or more identical switches in a level and it can get to be a real brain bender just to remember what switch does what. It feels like they could have used kept the overall look and feel of the game and still given you an indication of which switch you should be trying to get to to move a certain section.

8. I wouldn't say this gave me motion sickness or anything but every now and then after an hour or so of playing, I'd be like, "You know what, my eyes and brain need a break" and have to put it down for the day.

9. Most of the levels can be beaten in a matter of minutes if you know the solution but more than a couple of them took me over a half hour to solve. Sometimes, this was a result of good puzzle design. Other times, it was a result of me being, well, disoriented.

10. The issues discussed in 7 make it kind of hard to partially solve a level and come back to it later. Every thing is a sea of white. Nothing really sticks in the head so you can remember where you were or what you did.

11. There is no plot to this game whatever.

12. I will admit I looked up the answers to a few of these puzzles. To their credit, never once did I have a "I didn't even know I could do that" moment when doing this. The solutions were always right there in front of me, I just didn't see them. This is good.

13. I sincerely figured I'd pick up and finish this game in one sitting due to the low price and the play times on most reviews here but it's really a much more meaty experience than that. There's no real replay value in this unless you want to speed run it for some reason but this is an game you'll need some time to dig into--and it's worth it once you do.
 
LogicalFrank
1,407 produits enregistr√©s
0

Recommand√©
3.2 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 30 janvier 2017
This is not a puzzle game. Think of this game like a little 3d maze to wander around. Took me about 3 hours of play to beat, so for the price, it's not a bad little project. If you're looking for a portal-like manipulating the environment to solve puzzles, it's not that. But hey, it's fun and it's cheap, take a shot at it.
 
ShrivelingFire
0
Personne n'a trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Recommand√©
4.1 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 27 janvier 2017
Cute game, with a puzzle concept I haven't seen much before. The first dozen or so puzzles are very linear and thus easy even without understanding the structure you're walking through, but once you get near the end of the set of 30, the game gets trickier and trickier.

The update that released the last 6 stages truly completed the game. That last stage is a doozy! Takes about 3 hours to finish now.
 
McFrugal
